2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc: ALEKS provides multiple forms of feedback for both teachers and students. For teachers, the system generates detailed reports that go beyond percentage scores, offering insights such as student engagement time, assignment completion duration, and task completion rates. Teachers use these analytics to deliver targeted feedback on specific mathematical topics and individualized progress, often through discussions and goal-setting activities. Additionally, teachers incorporate ALEKS into classroom routines—such as warm-ups and remote sessions (due to the COVID pandemic)—to provide real-time feedback, correct errors, and guide students in using the tool effectively. For students, ALEKS offers immediate, automated feedback when answers are submitted, indicating correctness, providing hints, and enabling access to detailed explanations and extra practice opportunities.

3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over feedback timing through their interactions with ALEKS.

When students log into ALEKS, they can choose to work on their ALEKS My Path, a personalized learning pathway designed to help them master selected topics and complete their ALEKS Pie Chart. My Path provides structured tasks along with tools for managing time and tracking progress. As students engage with these tasks, ALEKS supports learning by offering immediate feedback and explanations. This includes indicating whether answers are correct or incorrect, providing hints, and allowing students to access more detailed explanations and additional practice opportunities.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Student progress and performance on assessments
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the ability of students to set their own learning goals and progress at their own pace. [whose agency? Students? Or teachers?]

Feedback informs students of right or wrong answers, provides hints, offers students the option to click on the program to get a more detailed explanation and additional practice. (p.508) "The reports generated in ALEKS can give teachers information beyond a percentage score or mastery level of a topic. (p.508) "ALEKS offers students explanations and immediate feedback when students input answers to ALEKS questions (ALEKS, 2021). (p.508). "Teachers gave feedback to students based on information they collected from the ALEKS data analysis tools. Some of the feedback they gave was based on specific math topics" [...] "teachers indicated they gave feedback to students about their individualized progress by having discussions with them or engaging in goal setting." (p.512) "Many of the teachers used ALEKS during class time to do “bell ringers” and “warm-ups”, described by teachers in this study as a set of problems for students to complete at the beginning of class. 2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc: The ASSISTments platform provides two feedback modes. In the immediate feedback with hints and reattempts condition, students receive instant correctness feedback after each attempt and can request up to four hints per problem. They must enter the correct answer before moving on, earning full credit if correct on the first try without hints, and partial credit with deductions for errors or hint use. After completing the set, students receive a second round of feedback and can review hints and correct answers. In contrast, the delayed feedback condition offers no hints or correctness feedback during problem-solving; students simply submit answers and proceed. After finishing, they access a session report with correctness feedback and hints, allowing them to revisit problems and review solutions.

3.2a Discussion points for agency: ASSISTments promotes student agency by giving learners control over their problem-solving process through the "immediate feedback and hints with reattempts" feedback condition. Students can request hints at any time, receive instant correctness feedback after each attempt, and retry problems until they reach the correct solution, which encourages persistence and self-regulation. The platform also provides detailed session reports that allow students to review their performance and revisit problems, supporting reflection and independent learning. These features enable students to actively monitor their progress, make decisions about when to seek help, and take ownership of improving their accuracy—key components of agency in learning.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Posttest scores, state test scores, percentage of problems completed, and percentage of problems answered correctly on the first attempt.

1.2 Context: Web-based homework system for mathematics education.
1.4 Tool/Platform: SANYMS (Show and Name Your Math Steps).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided at each step of problem-solving, allowing students to correct their work before moving on.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is immediate and specific to the step being attempted, which enhances learning by allowing students to correct errors in real-time.
2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc:
The Constraint-Based Tutor (CBT) provides feedback based on predefined constraints that include a relevance condition (when the rule applies) and a satisfaction condition (whether the student’s input is correct). If the relevance condition is met but the satisfaction condition fails, the system delivers a targeted feedback message. This approach allows students to follow any solution path as long as they do not violate constraints, promoting flexibility while ensuring correctness at each step.
SANYMS, a web-based homework system built on CBT principles, offers step-by-step feedback during algebra problem-solving. Students select an action (e.g., adding, multiplying, factoring) and input the resulting equation. If incorrect, they receive a prompt to retry before moving on, preventing error compounding. Unlike automated solvers, SANYMS keeps students in control of the solution process, requiring them to declare each step, which enables detection of correct answers achieved through incorrect reasoning. Integrated tools like a math keyboard minimize syntax errors, and the system ensures feedback is immediate, accurate, and aligned with the student’s chosen problem-solving path.
3.1 Agency type: Students can choose problem-solving steps.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control the timing of feedback by choosing when to submit their work.
3.2a Discussion points for agency: the Constraint-Based Tutor (CBT) and SANYMS give learners control over their problem-solving process while providing structured, non-intrusive feedback. CBT allows students to follow any solution path as long as constraints are satisfied, while SANYMS builds on this by requiring students to select and name each step, ensuring they actively decide how to proceed. Immediate, step-level feedback prevents error compounding without taking over the solution process, and the system distinguishes between syntactical mistakes, incorrect applications, and valid but unexpected forms. This design encourages autonomy, metacognitive reflection, and ownership of learning, enabling students to construct solutions independently rather than passively receiving answers.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Correctness of each step and overall solution.

Author: Tirado-Olivares, S; Mínguez-Pardo, R; del Olmo-Muñoz, J; González-Calero, JA
Title: Utilizing Learning-Analytics-Based Activities as a Bridge to Enhance Elementary Students' Mathematical Learning
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through real-time insights based on learning analytics data.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is formative and data-driven, allowing for real-time adjustments in teaching strategies.
2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc: The tool provides example-based (EB) learning feedback, which combines two types of instructional examples: correct examples (CE) and erroneous examples (EE). CE demonstrate accurate solutions and help students learn efficient problem-solving strategies, while EE expose common mistakes and misconceptions, prompting learners to reflect and correct their reasoning. These examples are integrated into short interactive tasks and videos on a Moodle-based platform, supported by learning analytics (LA) to monitor progress and predict future performance. The feedback is formative, allowing teachers to intervene early and tailor instruction based on real-time data. Importantly, the effectiveness of CE and EE depends on students’ prior knowledge—those with lower initial understanding benefit more from CE, whereas differences diminish for higher-achieving students. This approach not only reinforces conceptual understanding but also provides teachers with actionable insights to personalize learning.
3.1 Agency type: Students have flexibility over the learning pace and task completion.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over feedback timing as they complete tasks at their own pace.
3.2a Discussion points for agency: The tool promotes student agency by enabling learners to work autonomously on short, interactive tasks through a Moodle-based platform, supported by Learning Analytics (LA). Students receive immediate feedback, can monitor their progress, and access explanatory videos, which fosters self-regulation and informed decision-making. LA provides real-time data that allows teachers to personalize instruction while empowering students to take ownership of their learning. The inclusion of correct and erroneous examples encourages reflection and deeper cognitive engagement, while the flexibility to complete tasks at their own pace enhances autonomy. Overall, this design combines adaptive feedback, transparency, and meaningful activities to create a student-centered learning environment that strengthens agency.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pretest and posttest scores, student engagement metrics.
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student engagement and performance metrics on tasks.

Author: Oker, A; Pecune, F; Declercq, C
Title: Virtual tutor and pupil interaction: A study of empathic feedback as extrinsic motivation for learning
2.2 Description of context: Feedback provided through verbal and facial expressions
2.3 Our evaluation: Feedback is perceived as more effective when empathic
2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc: The virtual agents provided formative feedback that combined both verbal and nonverbal elements to enhance engagement and motivation. Verbal feedback delivered learning content and evaluations, while nonverbal cues—such as facial expressions, gaze direction, gestures, and voice modulation—were designed to convey empathy and stimulate interest in the task. Using the Facial Action Coding System (FACS), the agents generated realistic facial expressions to appear empathic, which activated learners’ mirror neuron systems and fostered a sense of connection. This multimodal feedback aimed not only to correct or guide performance but also to boost extrinsic motivation and engagement, leading to improved accuracy and faster responses in learning tasks.
3.1 Agency type: Student active partication and interaction with a virtual agent
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified
3.2a Discussion points for agency: virtual agents designed with empathic feedback significantly enhance students’ motivation and engagement. Using the VIB platform, the researchers compared a unimodal agent (verbal feedback only) with a bimodal agent (verbal feedback plus facial expressions based on the Facial Action Coding System). Children interacting with the bimodal agent achieved higher accuracy (84% vs. 74%), took more time to respond—indicating deeper cognitive engagement—and perceived the agent as more caring and supportive. These empathic cues encouraged students to persist longer and make extra effort, boosting their extrinsic motivation and sense of agency. The findings suggest that multimodal, empathic feedback humanizes digital learning environments, fostering active participation and improved performance even in familiar tasks.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy rates, reaction times, and questionnaire responses

Author: Colliot, T; Krichen, O; Girard, N; Anquetil, E; Jamet, E
Title: What makes tablet-based learning effective? A study of the role of real-time adaptive feedback
1.3 Tech/AI type: Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) with real-time adaptive feedback.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided immediately after drawing segments or angles, indicating correctness with color coding (green for correct, red for incorrect).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is immediate and corrective, which aligns with the paper's focus on enhancing learning through real-time feedback.
2.3a Discussion points for feedback proc: The tool provides real-time, AI-driven corrective and adaptive feedback during geometry exercises. As students draw segments or angles, the system instantly displays visual cues—turning elements green if correct or red if incorrect—so learners can actively infer why their responses are right or wrong. This immediate feedback supports performance and learning, particularly for novices, by guiding them toward accurate solutions without giving away full answers. The study found that this feedback was highly effective: students who received it not only performed better during practice but also showed significantly improved results on a subsequent paper-based transfer task, even without feedback. This demonstrates that real-time corrective feedback enhances short-term accuracy and fosters durable learning, helping students become more autonomous as guidance is gradually reduced.
3.1 Agency type: Students are encouraged to regulate their own learning and reflect but feedback is controlled by the system.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; it is provided automatically by the system.
3.2a Discussion points for agency: The tool promotes student agency by enabling learners to actively monitor and regulate their own progress through real-time adaptive feedback. As students draw geometric shapes on the tablet, the AI system immediately signals correctness by turning segments or angles green if correct and red if incorrect. This instant, visual feedback allows students to identify and correct mistakes on their own, fostering autonomy and self-directed learning rather than relying on teacher intervention. The study emphasizes that this feedback encourages learners to engage in active reasoning—figuring out why an angle is right or wrong—and gradually improves their performance over time. Moreover, because students successfully applied what they learned to a paper-based transfer task without further feedback, the approach supports durable learning and independence. The authors argue that such adaptive guidance, combined with the possibility of tapering support as students gain expertise, helps transform novices into autonomous learners.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Success in drawing geometric shapes and angle differences.
